items.title: Organisation
items.text:
This repository defines the development foundation of the project. It serves as a central reference for coding standards, documentation practices, and workflow conventions that ensure consistency and quality across all contributions.

Its purpose is to align engineering practices, reduce ambiguity, and provide a shared understanding of how software is developed, documented, and maintained.

items.title: Structure of This Repository
items.text: The repository is organized into three main sections:

items.title: C Coding Guidelines
items.text:
Open C Coding Guidelines

Defines mandatory rules and best practices for all C source code, including:

  • File and project structure
  • Header and source separation
  • API declaration principles
  • Naming conventions and formatting
  • Error handling patterns
  • Testing expectations
  • Tooling and build requirements

The goal is predictable, readable, and production-ready embedded code.

items.title: Git Documentation
items.text:
Open Git Documentation

Describes how version control is used in this project, including:

  • Repository access and authentication
  • Branching strategy and naming conventions
  • Pull request workflow
  • Review and integration process
  • Quality gates and recovery procedures

The goal is a clean history, stable integration, and reproducible development workflows.

items.title: Writing Formal Documentation
items.text:
Open Writing Guidelines

Provides guidance for writing structured and verifiable embedded requirements and C API documentation, including:

  • Functional and non-functional requirements
  • Hardware interface specifications
  • API documentation principles
  • Verification strategies
  • Normative wording conventions

The goal is clear, measurable, and testable documentation.

items.title: Overall Objective
items.text:
This repository promotes:

  • Consistent engineering standards
  • Clear and traceable requirements
  • High-quality, maintainable code
  • Structured documentation
  • Controlled and predictable development processes

All contributors are expected to follow the guidelines defined in the respective sections to ensure technical consistency and long-term project stability.

items.title: About
items.text:
The documentation is built with zensical and uses uv for reproducible dependency management and environment handling.

If your question is not addressed in this repository, please reach out via Telegram or email.

items.title: Prerequisites
items.text:
• Python ‚â• 3.12 installed
  • uv installed (https://docs.astral.sh/uv/)

You can install uv system-wide or inside a virtual environment if preferred.

items.title: Install Dependencies
items.text:
From the repository root:

uv sync

This creates a local virtual environment and installs all dependencies defined in pyproject.toml and locked in uv.lock.

items.title: Development Server
items.text:
Start the live development server:

uv run dev

The documentation will be served locally (default: http://localhost:9000).

items.title: Build Static Site
items.text:
To generate the static documentation site:

uv run build

The generated output will be placed in ./site

items.title: Clean Reinstall
items.text:
If the environment becomes inconsistent:

uv sync --reinstall

This fully recreates the environment from the lockfile.

items.title: Notes
items.text:
• Do not manually activate .venv
  • Do not use pip
  • Do not modify uv.lock manually
  • Commit both pyproject.toml and uv.lock to ensure reproducibility

The setup is fully deterministic and CI-friendly.

items.title: C Standard
items.text:
• Standard: C99
  • Compatibility: ANSI-C
  • Compiler Flags: See Compiler

items.title: Project Structure
items.text: A typical C project will consist of multiple directories and, in our case, some configuration files.

items.title: Folder Structure
items.text:
The structure looks like this:

root/
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ src/      # All source files and private headers
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ include/  # Public headers containing the external API
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ test/     # Unit tests and test runners
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ html/     # folder for compiled docs and coverage report
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ build/    # Build artifacts and temporary files
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ example/  # Reference implementations or examples
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ docs/     # Project documentation

items.title: Config Files
items.text: File Purpose makefile Defines build targets, compiler flags, and project dependencies. .clang-format Enforces a consistent code style across all contributors. .gitignore Specifies which files and directories should be ignored by Git (e.g., build/, .gcda, .o). Doxyfile Configuration file for Doxygen ‚Äî used to generate reference documentation from source code comments. README.md Describes the project, setup instructions, and usage overview.

items.title: Notes
items.text:
• All internal logic and private headers reside in src/.
  • All headers that form the public API should be placed under include/.
  • Build artifacts (object files, coverage data, binaries) should always go into build/ and not be committed.
  • html/ should also never be committed as it is beeing built dynamically in the pipeline.
  • Documentation generated from Doxygen will usually be placed under docs/ and can be auto-generated using a Makefile target like make docs.
  • Example implementations and documentation should remain in their dedicated directories for clarity and consistency.

items.title: Home / C Coding Guidelines
items.text:
This document defines the mandatory coding standards and development rules for all C code in this project.

It establishes:

  • File structure and project organization
  • Header and source file responsibilities
  • API declaration rules
  • Function structure and ordering
  • Naming conventions
  • Formatting and style requirements
  • Error handling patterns
  • Testing requirements
  • Build and tooling expectations

The goal is:

  • Clear and predictable code structure
  • Strict separation between interface and implementation
  • High readability and maintainability
  • Deterministic and testable behavior
  • Consistent formatting across the entire codebase
  • Production-ready, reviewable code at all times

All contributors are expected to follow these guidelines without exception.

items.title: General Rules
items.text:
• English names shall be used.
  • Descriptive names like total_amount are preferred over abbreviations like ta.

items.title: Variables
items.text:
• Use snake_case.
int total_amount;
float current_speed_rpm;

items.title: Functions
items.text:
• Use snake_case.
int module_name_of_function(void) {
    return 0;
}

items.title: Typedefs
items.text:
• Use CamelCase for structs, enums, and other typedefs.
typedef struct ExampleStruct {
    int example_int;
} ExampleStruct;

items.title: Struct Members
items.text:
• Use snake_case.
typedef struct MotorController {
    int current_speed_rpm;
    int target_speed_rpm;
} MotorController;

items.title: Enums
items.text:
• Enum type name ‚Üí CamelCase
  • Enum values ‚Üí UPPER_CASE
  • Assign actual values to the enum values.
typedef enum SystemState {
    SYSTEM_STATE_INIT     = 0,
    SYSTEM_STATE_RUNNING  = 1,
    SYSTEM_STATE_ERROR    = 2
} SystemState;

items.title: Macros
items.text:
• Use UPPER_CASE with underscores.
#define MAX_BUFFER_SIZE 256
#define DEFAULT_TIMEOUT_MS 1000
#define MIN(a, b) ((a) < (b) ? (a) : (b))

items.title: Constants
items.text:
• Constants are treated like variables ‚Üí snake_case.
static const int default_timeout_ms = 1000;
const float pi_approx = 3.1415926f;

items.title: Include Guards
items.text:
Every header file must use include guards.

  • Uppercase
  • File path based
  • _H suffix
  • No leading/trailing underscores
  • No double underscores
#ifndef MOTOR_CONTROLLER_H
#define MOTOR_CONTROLLER_H

/* content */

#endif /* MOTOR_CONTROLLER_H */

items.title: Include Order
items.text:
The include order shall be following.

  1. Own header
  2. C Standard libaries headers
  3. Third-Party headers
  4. Project headers
#include "motor_controller.h"

#include <stdint.h>
#include <stdbool.h>

#include "can_bus.h"
#include "pwm_driver.h"

items.title: File Naming
items.text:
• File names use snake_case.
  • One module per .c / .h pair.

Examples:

  • motor_controller.c
  • motor_controller.h
  • can_bus.c
  • can_bus.h

items.title: Pointer Style
items.text:
• The * belongs to the name.
int *buffer;
char *message;
const uint8_t *rx_data;
MotorController *controller;

items.title: Visibility Rules
items.text:
• Public API functions are declared in header files.
  • Internal functions are declared static and remain inside the .c file.

items.title: Booleans
items.text:
• Use <stdbool.h>.

  • Prefix boolean variables with:

  • is_

  • has_
  • can_
  • should_
bool is_initialized;
bool has_error;

items.title: Core
items.text: Tool Purpose gcc GNU Compiler Collection ‚Äî compiles C source code into executables. make Automates builds and handles dependency tracking and incremental compilation. clang-format Formats all C source files according to a consistent style guide. gdb GNU Debugger ‚Äî allows step-through debugging, breakpoints, and variable inspection.

items.title: Testing
items.text: Tool Purpose Unity Lightweight unit testing framework for C. Provides easy test creation and integration with Make and coverage tools. gcovr Collects and summarizes gcov output into clean console, HTML, or XML reports.

items.title: Compiler
items.text: We use GCC as our compiler since it is available across all major platforms and provides all the features required for this project. For installation and setup instructions, see the Installation section.

items.title: Compiler Flags
items.text:
To ensure consistent behavior, code quality, and compatibility, the following compiler flags are used:

Flag Purpose -std=c99 Enforces the C99 standard for consistent syntax and features. -pedantic Ensures strict adherence to the ANSI/ISO C standard. -Wall Enables common compiler warnings to catch potential issues. -Wextra Enables additional warnings for more thorough code analysis. -Werror Treats all warnings as errors to enforce clean builds.

items.title: Coverage and Testing Flags
items.text:
For files that are subject to testing and coverage reporting, additional flags are required:

Flag Purpose -fprofile-arcs Generates extra code to record execution paths for coverage analysis. -ftest-coverage Creates coverage data files (.gcno, .gcda) used by coverage tools. -lgcov Links against the gcov library to enable runtime profiling support.

These flags ensure that builds are standard-compliant, warning-free, and coverage-enabled where applicable.

items.title: Testing and Coverage
items.text:
For testing, we use Unity ‚Äî a lightweight and portable unit testing framework designed for C projects, particularly embedded systems.

‚ÄúANSI-C compatible embedded software that just works.‚Äù

Unity is well-suited for this project because it:

  • Requires no external dependencies
  • Works on bare-metal and hosted environments
  • Supports custom test runners and integration with CI pipelines

To integrate Unity into a project, simply include the following files:

  • unity.c
  • unity.h
  • unity_internals.h

An example implementation can be found in the tests directory.

items.title: Coverage
items.text:
Code coverage reports are generated using the coverage data produced by GCC and processed with the Python tool gcovr. gcovr reads .gcno and .gcda files created during compilation and execution, and then generates detailed reports in multiple formats, such as HTML, XML, or text summaries.

Example usage:

gcovr -r . --html --html-details -o coverage.html

These reports can be automatically published via GitHub Pages, ensuring easy access to coverage metrics for every commit or pull request.

An example pipeline for automated testing and coverage generation is provided at: tests/.github/actions/on_push.yaml

items.title: Make
items.text: Make is a build automation tool used to compile and manage projects efficiently. It reads a file called a Makefile, which defines targets, dependencies, and commands that describe how to build or clean project files.

items.title: How It Works
items.text:
A basic rule in a Makefile looks like this:

target: dependencies
    command

When you run:

make target

Make checks if the dependencies have changed since the target was last built. If they have, it runs the command to rebuild the target.

You will find an example makefile at example/makefile.

items.title: Common Targets
items.text:
Typical targets in C projects include:

Target Purpose all Builds the entire project. clean Removes all compiled files and build artifacts. test Builds and runs all unit tests. coverage Generates a code coverage report.

Example usage:

make all      # Build the project
make clean    # Remove build artifacts
make test     # Run unit tests
make coverage # Generate coverage report

items.title: Why Use Make
items.text:
• Automates repetitive build steps
  • Only recompiles what changed
  • Portable ‚Äî works across platforms with GCC or other compilers
  • Integrates easily with CI/CD pipelines

In short, Make simplifies project building, testing, and maintenance by automating compilation and linking based on file changes.

items.title: Doxygen
items.text:
Doxygen is a documentation generation tool for C, C++, and other languages. It parses source code and specially formatted comments to create structured documentation in HTML, LaTeX, or man formats.

Doxygen helps maintain up-to-date technical documentation directly alongside your codebase, ensuring consistency between implementation and documentation.

items.title: Purpose
items.text:
In this project, Doxygen is used to:

  • Automatically generate documentation for functions, structs, and macros from annotated comments.
  • Create browsable HTML documentation for developers.
  • Visualize dependencies and call relationships.
  • Enforce a unified documentation style across the team.
  • Integrate documentation generation into CI/CD pipelines.

items.title: Doxyfile Configuration
items.text:
Doxygen is controlled through a configuration file named Doxyfile, located in the project root.

To create a new one (if not already present), run:

doxygen -g

Then edit the generated file to match the project‚Äôs layout. A minimal configuration might look like this:

PROJECT_NAME           = "LaEracing C Project"
OUTPUT_DIRECTORY       = docs/doxygen
INPUT                  = src include
RECURSIVE              = YES
EXTRACT_PRIVATE        = YES
EXTRACT_STATIC         = YES
GENERATE_HTML          = YES
GENERATE_LATEX         = NO
WARN_IF_UNDOCUMENTED   = YES

This setup will generate HTML documentation under docs/doxygen/.

items.title: Doxywizard
items.text: Doxywizard is a graphical interface for Doxygen that allows editing and running documentation generation without manually modifying the Doxyfile. It is installed alongside Doxygen and provides an intuitive way to configure and visualize output. You can find official Doxywizard documentation here: üëâ https://www.doxygen.nl/manual/doxywizard_usage.html

items.title: Writing Doxygen Comments
items.text: Doxygen supports several comment styles. Common patterns include:

items.title: File Header Example
items.text:
/**
 * @file motor_controller.c
 * @brief Implements motor control logic and safety mechanisms.
 * @date 2025-11-09
 * @version 1.0
 */

items.title: Function Documentation Example
items.text:
/**
 * @brief Initializes the motor controller.
 *
 * Sets up PWM channels and performs a self-check.
 *
 * @param[in] config Pointer to the configuration structure.
 * @return `0` on success, non-zero error code otherwise.
 */
int motor_init(const MotorConfig* config);

items.title: Struct Example
items.text:
/**
 * @struct MotorConfig
 * @brief Holds configuration parameters for the motor controller.
 */
typedef struct MotorConfig{
    int max_speed;
    int min_speed;
} MotorConfig;

items.title: Generating Documentation
items.text: You can generate documentation either from the terminal or via Doxywizard.

items.title: Using Terminal
items.text:
doxygen Doxyfile

Output will be located at:

docs/doxygen/html/index.html

items.title: Summary
items.text:
• Doxygen converts annotated code comments into readable documentation.
  • Doxywizard provides a GUI for easier configuration and generation.
  • Documentation is generated under docs/doxygen/ and can be published automatically via GitHub Pages or CI/CD.

items.title: Linux
items.text: All major Linux distributions already include GCC and Make in their repositories.

items.title: Debian/Ubuntu
items.text:
sudo apt update
sudo apt install build-essential git -y

items.title: Fedora/RHEL
items.text: sudo dnf install gcc make git

items.title: Arch Linux
items.text:
sudo pacman -S base-devel git

After installation, confirm everything works:

gcc --version
make --version

items.title: Installing brew
items.text:
/bin/bash -c "$(curl -fsSL https://raw.githubusercontent.com/Homebrew/install/HEAD/install.sh)"
  • Follow post-install actions (add brew to path etc.)

items.title: Installing tools
items.text:
brew install gcc gdb
brew install clang-format
brew install doxygen
brew install make cmake

After installation, confirm everything works:

gcc --version
make --version

items.title: Windows
items.text: For gcovr to work, you have to have installed Python on your system. To see the installation process, please refer to requirements.md.

items.title: Installing MSYS
items.text:
If you do not have MSYS installed yet, download it from msys2.org. After installation, you will have several bash environments available. You can use those directly, but we recommend adding the environment to your PATH, so you can run gcc, make, or pacman directly from your regular Windows Terminal or PowerShell.

We use the UCRT64 environment because it works best with Windows 10 and newer, thanks to Microsoft‚Äôs modern Universal C Runtime (UCRT) toolchain. This environment offers better compatibility, stability, and Unicode support than the older MSVCRT-based ones.

items.title: Adding to PATH
items.text:
To add the UCRT64 environment to your PATH permanently, open an administrator PowerShell window and run:

[Environment]::SetEnvironmentVariable("Path", $env:Path + ";C:\msys64\ucrt64\bin;C:\msys64\usr\bin", "Machine")

After that, restart PowerShell or Command Prompt, and verify that MSYS2 is correctly available by checking pacman:

pacman -V

You should see output similar to:

Pacman v6.1.0 - libalpm v14.1.0

If this works, your MSYS environment is set up correctly. If not, ensure your PATH variable is correct and that MSYS2 is installed under C:\msys64\.

items.title: Installing the Tooling
items.text:
Once MSYS2 is installed, you‚Äôll need to install the essential build tools. In an MSYS2 UCRT64 terminal or your normal terminal if added to PATH, run:

pacman -S --needed --noconfirm mingw-w64-ucrt-x86_64-gcc mingw-w64-ucrt-x86_64-gdb mingw-w64-ucrt-x86_64-make mingw-w64-ucrt-x86_64-clang-tools-extra mingw-w64-ucrt-x86_64-clang

items.title: WSL (Windows Subsystem for Linux)
items.text:
If you prefer a fully native Linux environment on Windows, WSL is a great option.

Installation steps:

  1. Enable WSL (Windows Subsystem for Linux) from Windows Features or run:
wsl --install
  1. Install Ubuntu (recommended) or another Linux distribution from the Microsoft Store.
  2. Open your WSL terminal and install the required build tools:
sudo apt update
sudo apt install build-essential git -y
  1. Verify your setup:
gcc --version
make --version

items.title: What is git?
items.text:
Git is a distributed version control system. Core concepts:

  • Repository (repo) -> Project with history
  • Commit -> snapshot of changes
  • Branch -> movable poitner to commits
  • HEAD -> current position
  • Remote -> hosted repo (e.g. on GitHub)
  • Staging Area -> what will go in the next commit

items.title: Git Basics
items.text: currently just look at git.presentation

items.title: main
items.text:
• Production Branch
  • Always deployable
  • Protected on GitHub
  • No direct commits
  • No merges outside Pull Requests(PR's)

items.title: feature/nameOfFeature
items.text:
• Feature Branch
  • Should be deployable
  • Non-Protected
  • No direct commits if sub-issue branches exist
  • Typically no merges outside PR's

items.title: feature/nameOfFeature/nameOfSubIssue
items.text:
• Issue Branch
  • Active developement of the issue
  • Non-Protected
  • Direct commits
  • Typically no merges outside PR's

items.title: fix/nameOfFix
items.text:
• Bugfix Branch
  • Active fixing of Bug
  • Non-Protected
  • Direct commits
  • Typically no merges outside PR's

items.title: Cheatsheet
items.text: Quick reference for daily workflow.

items.title: Clone (SSH)
items.text:
git clone git@github.com:org/repo.git
cd repo

items.title: Start Working on a Sub-Issue
items.text:
git checkout main
git pull --rebase
git checkout -b feature/nameOfFeature/nameOfIssue

items.title: Check Status
items.text: git status

items.title: Stage Changes
items.text:
git add <file>
git add .

items.title: Commit (Signed Automatically)
items.text: git commit -m "Add CAN timeout validation"

items.title: Update Branch Before Push
items.text: git pull --rebase origin main

items.title: Push Branch
items.text: git push -u origin feature/nameOfFeature/nameOfIssue

items.title: Fix Last Commit (Before Push)
items.text: git commit --amend

items.title: Interactive Rebase (Local Cleanup)
items.text:
git rebase -i HEAD~n

After rebase:

git push --force-with-lease

(Only allowed on own branch and after approval if required.)

items.title: Revert a Commit (Safe on Shared Branches)
items.text: git revert <commit-hash>

items.title: Resolve Conflict
items.text:
# edit file
git add <file>
git rebase --continue

Abort:

git rebase --abort

items.title: Delete Branch After Merge
items.text:
Local:

git branch -d feature/nameOfFeature/nameOfIssue

Remote:

git push origin --delete feature/nameOfFeature/nameOfIssue

items.title: View History
items.text: git log --oneline --graph --decorate

items.title: Check Remotes
items.text: git remote -v

items.title: Coverage Reminder
items.text:
Before opening PR:

  • ‚â• 90% unit test coverage
  • CI green
  • All sub-issues resolved
  • Feature complete

items.title: Home / How To Git
items.text:
This document defines how Git and GitHub are used in this project.

It establishes:

  • How repositories are accessed and authenticated (SSH, signing)
  • How branches are structured and named
  • How features and issues are organized
  • How Pull Requests are reviewed and merged
  • What quality and coverage requirements must be met
  • How mistakes are recovered safely
  • What rules are mandatory for all contributors

The goal is:

  • A stable production branch
  • Traceable and clean history
  • High test reliability
  • Controlled integration through review
  • Predictable and reproducible development workflow

All contributors are expected to follow the rules and processes defined in this guide.

items.title: Important Rules
items.text:
• Never commit directly on main
  • Always use ssh
  • Always use signed commits (Pull Requests will not be able to merge if not)
  • Write clear commit messages
  • Keep commits small and focused

items.title: Initial Setup
items.text: For the configuration please use the Git Bash if you have not setup your PATH yet.

items.title: Set identity
items.text:
git config --global user.name "Your Name"
git config --global user.email "your@email.com"

For Usage with GitHub it is essential to have the same email as your GitHub profile.

items.title: Set default branch to main
items.text:
Since Git 3.0 main is the default branch instead of the previous master.

git config --global init.defaultBranch main

items.title: Recommended
items.text:
git config --global pull.rebase false
git config --global core.editor "code --wait"

items.title: SSH Authentication (GitHub)
items.text: Do not use HTTPS + passwords. Use SSH.

items.title: Generate SSH Key
items.text: ssh-keygen -t ed25519 -C "you@domain.com"

items.title: Activate for your OS
items.text:
Accept default path:

~/.ssh/id_ed25519

Start agent:

eval "$(ssh-agent -s)"
ssh-add ~/.ssh/id_ed25519

items.title: Copy public key
items.text:
cat ~/.ssh/id_ed25519.pub

On GitHub:

  1. Go to Settings
  2. SSH and GPG Keys
  3. New SSH key
  4. Paste Key

items.title: Test Connection
items.text:
ssh -T git@github.com

Expected:

Hi <username>! You've successfully authenticated...

items.title: SSH Signing (GitHub)
items.text: On our Repos commit signing, so you have to enable it. This ensures commits are cryptographically verifiied on GitHub.

items.title: Enable SSH Signing in Git
items.text:
git config --global gpg.format ssh
git config --global user.signingkey ~/.ssh/id_ed25519.pub
git config --global commit.gpgsign true

items.title: Add Signing Key to GitHub
items.text:
In GitHub:

  1. Settings
  2. SSH and GPG Keys
  3. New SSH Key
  4. Select Signing Key
  5. Paste the same public Key

items.title: Test Signed Commit
items.text:
In a tmp directory initialize a git repo.

git init

Then create a test commit.

git commit --allow-empty -m "Test commit"

Check:

git log --show-signature

Expected output should be:

Good "git" signature for <username>...

items.title: Troubleshooting
items.text: If you are unsure just contact someone via e.g. Telegram before changing anything.

items.title: Discard Unstaged Changes
items.text:
git restore <file>

Discard all local unstaged changes:

git restore .

items.title: Unstage Files
items.text: git restore --staged <file>

items.title: Amend Last Commit (Before Push)
items.text:
git commit --amend

Use only if: - Commit is not pushed - You are on your own branch

items.title: Fixing a Wrong Commit (Not Yet Pushed)
Soft Reset (Keep Changes)
items.text:
git reset --soft HEAD~1

Moves HEAD back one commit but keeps changes staged.

items.title: Mixed Reset (Keep Changes Unstaged)
items.text: git reset HEAD~1

items.title: Hard Reset (Dangerous)
items.text:
git reset --hard HEAD~1

Removes commit and changes permanently.

Use only if: - Changes are not needed - Commit was not pushed

items.title: Fixing a Pushed Commit (Feature Branch)
items.text:
If the branch is not shared, you may:

git rebase -i HEAD~n

Then:

git push --force-with-lease

Allowed only if:

  • It is your own branch
  • No one else is working on it
  • No admin restriction applies

If unsure, contact admin.

items.title: Never Rewrite main
items.text:
• Do not rebase main
  • Do not reset main
  • Do not force push to main
  • Fix issues via a new PR

items.title: Revert a Commit (Safe for Shared Branches)
items.text:
If something is already merged to main:

git revert <commit-hash>

Creates a new commit that undoes the change.

Push normally and open a PR if required.

items.title: Handling Conflicts
items.text:
When rebasing or merging:

<<<<<<< HEAD
current changes
=======
incoming changes
>>>>>>> branch

Resolution flow:

  1. Edit file
  2. Remove conflict markers
  3. Stage file:
git add <file>
  1. Continue:
git rebase --continue

Abort if needed:

git rebase --abort

items.title: Detached HEAD
items.text:
If you see:

You are in 'detached HEAD' state

Fix by switching to a branch:

git checkout main

Or create a branch from current state:

git checkout -b feature/new-branch

items.title: Lost Commits Recovery
items.text:
Use reflog:

git reflog

Find commit hash, then:

git checkout <hash>

Or restore:

git reset --hard <hash>

items.title: Accidentally Committed to Wrong Branch
items.text:
If not pushed:

git reset --soft HEAD~1
git checkout correct-branch
git commit

If pushed to a feature branch: - Fix on that branch\

  • Or revert

If pushed to main: - Immediately inform admin\

  • Create revert PR

items.title: CI Fails After Merge
items.text:
1. Identify failing job
  2. Fix issue in a new branch
  3. Open hotfix PR
  4. Follow full review process

Never push directly to main to apply a quick fix.

items.title: When to Contact Admin
items.text:
• Accidental push to main
  • Force push required
  • Branch protection violation
  • Corrupted history
  • Unrecoverable merge situation

items.title: Developement Workflow
items.text: Mandatory for every developement effort.

items.title: 1. Create a Feature Issue
items.text:
• Tagged with Type Feature
  • Labelled according to its functionality
  • Represents a complete Feature
  • Assigned to maintainer
  • According branch is created (seeRules)

Example: Implementation of CAN Interface

items.title: 2. Create Sub-Issues
items.text:
• Labelled according to its functionality
  • Represents one developement part of a Feature
  • Assigned to maintainer
  • According branch is created (seeRules)

Example: Implementation of Error Handling in CAN Interface

items.title: 3. Create Pull Request
items.text:
• Created from dev branch to merge branch
  • Assigned to maintainer
  • Reviewer assigned accordingly
  • Converted to draft until review is expected

items.title: When to expect review
items.text:
• Feature / issue is fully implemented
  • @Feature: Minimum 90% unit test coverage except valid explanation
  • @Feature: All tests pass
  • @Feature: CI passes

items.title: Review
items.text: The reviewer evaluates the Pull Request according to:

items.title: Functional Correctness
items.text:
• Feature fulfills the main issue description
  • All sub-issues are resolved

items.title: Test Coverage
items.text:
• Minimum 90% unit test coverage except with valid explanation
  • New logic is covered by tests
  • Edge cases are tested
  • Tests are deterministic and stable
  • All CI checks are green

items.title: Code Quality
items.text:
• Clear and consistent naming
  • Small, focused commits
  • No uneccassary complexity
  • No duplicated logic
  • No dead code

items.title: Architecture & Design
items.text:
• Conforms to project structure
  • No violations of layering or modular boundaries
  • No hidden coupling introduced
  • Interfaces remain clean and stable

items.title: Git Hygiene
items.text:
• Correct branch naming (feature/nameOfFeature/nameOfIssue)
  • Signed commits
  • Clean commit history
  • No unrelated changes

Non-feature PRs are handled more flexibly at the discretion of the reviewer and assignee.

items.title: Approval means
items.text:
• Reviewer explicitly approves in GitHub
  • No unresolved review comments.

items.title: If issues arrise
items.text:
1. Reviewer adds review comments
  2. Reviewer requests changes
  3. Assignee addresses the feedback and fixes the issues
  4. Assignee re-requests review

items.title: Merge
items.text:
The assigned maintainer merges the Pull Request only after:

  • Reviewer approval
  • All CI checks pass
  • 90%+ coverage is verified

items.title: Merge Rules
items.text:
• Only the assigned maintainer may merge
  • No self-merging
  • No merging without review

items.title: Merge Method
items.text: Merge without squash

items.title: Post Merge
items.text:
The assignee must:

  • Verify CI completion on the target branch
  • Address hotfixes immediately
  • Delete the development branch
  • Close the issue and Pull Request if not done automatically

items.title: C API Documentation
items.text:
For embedded systems, the C API is part of the external interface. The API documentation should define:

  • Public functions.
  • Parameters
  • Return Values
  • Units
  • Error Handling
  • Preconditions
  • Postconditions

items.title: API Design Principles
items.text:
Good embedded APIs should:

  • Be deterministic
  • Avoid dynamic memory
  • Avoid hidden blocking behavior
  • Clearly define ownership of data
  • Return explicit status codes.
  • Functions should return status codes directly and provide additional output values via pointer parameters.

items.title: Requirements
items.text:
• The module must provide an initialization function that configures internal state and validates configuration parameters.
  • The function motor_update must complete execution within 200 ¬µs ¬±10 %.
  • All public functions must return a defined status code.

items.title: Result API
items.text:
#ifndef MOTOR_CONTROLLER_H
#define MOTOR_CONTROLLER_H

typedef enum MotorStatus {
    MOTOR_OK                    =  0,
    MOTOR_ERROR_INVALID_PARAM   = -1,
    MOTOR_ERROR_NOT_INITIALIZED = -2,
    MOTOR_ERROR_HW_FAILURE      = -3
} MotorStatus;

/**
 * @brief Initializes the motor module.
 *
 * @param config Pointer to configuration structure.
 *
 * @return MOTOR_OK if initialization was successful.
 *         MOTOR_ERROR_INVALID_PARAM if config is NULL.
 */
MotorStatus motor_init(const MotorConfig *config);

/**
 * @brief Executes one control cycle.
 *
 * Must be called every 5 ms.
 *
 * @return MOTOR_OK if execution completed successfully.
 */
MotorStatus motor_update(void);

#endif /* MOTOR_CONTROLLER_H */

items.title: Avoid the following
items.text:
• Hidden or undocumented timing assumptions
  • Undefined behavior in edge or fault conditions
  • Missing error states or undefined error handling
  • Missing units in numerical requirements
  • Undefined calling context (ISR, task, thread-safe)

items.title: Bad
items.text: The function must not block Problem: block is non-measurable

items.title: Better
items.text: The function must return within 50 ¬µs and must not wait for hardware events.

items.title: What should be covered?
items.text:
For embedded systems requirements typically define:

  • System behavior
  • Timing constraints
  • Hardware interaction
  • Error handling
  • Resource limitations
  • Public C Interface (API)

They should describe what the software does, not how it does it.

The document should be structured like the this:

  1. Introduction
  2. System Overview
  3. Functional Requirements
  4. Non-functional Requirements
  5. Hardware Interface Requirements
  6. Public C API Specifications
  7. Constraints
  8. Verification Strategy

items.title: Writing Principles
items.text:
Requirements should be:

  • Clear and unambiguous
  • Measurable
  • Testable
  • Aware of hardware constraints
  • Free from implementation details

items.title: Avoid Ambiguity
items.text:
Avoid using vague or subject terms such as:

  • fast
  • lightweight
  • efficient
  • stable If performance or quality attributes are required, they should be expressed using measurable criteria.

items.title: Home / Embedded Requirements Guideline
items.text:
This document defines how embedded software requirements and C API documentation are written in this project.

It establishes:

  • What aspects embedded requirements should cover
  • How functional and non-functional requirements are defined
  • How hardware interaction is specified
  • How timing, memory, and CPU constraints are documented
  • How public C APIs are structured and described
  • How requirements are verified
  • Which wording conventions are used

The goal is:

  • Clear and unambiguous requirements
  • Measurable and testable definitions
  • Consistent API documentation
  • Reduced ambiguity during implementation
  • Improved review and verification quality

This document serves as a practical guideline. It promotes structured and precise documentation while remaining adaptable to project-specific needs.

Contributors are expected to follow the principles described in this guide to ensure consistent and high-quality requirements.

items.title: Keep it Professional but readable
items.text: This document serves as a guideline rather than a strict specification. Its purpose is to promote clarity, consistency, and quality in embedded software requirements. It is not intended to restrict reasonable engineering judgment. Deviations are acceptable if they improve clarity or better suit the specific project context. For example, if a tabular overview of all API functions including inputs and outputs improves readability, it should be used. The document may be refined or adapted after internal review or peer feedback.

items.title: Normative Language
items.text: Requirements shall follow the terminology defined in RFC2119 with minor adaptations. The following keywords indicate the level of a requirement.

items.title: Must/Shall
items.text: Indicates an absolute requirement. (‚ÄúREQUIRED‚Äù may also be used)

items.title: Must Not/Shall Not
items.text: Indicates an absolute prohibition.

items.title: Should/Recommend
items.text: Indicates a strong recommendation. Valid reasons may exist to deviate, but the implications should be understood.

items.title: Should Not/Not Recommended
items.text: Indicates that a behavior is generally discouraged, but exceptions may exist.

items.title: May/Optional
items.text: Indicates that an item is optional.

items.title: Use of TBD
items.text:
TBD indicates that a detail has not yet been decided. TBD items should be avoided where possible. If used, additional context or expected directions should be provided in brackets. TBD items can be highlighted by a red colorization.

TBD (expected ADC resolution: 12-16 bit)

items.title: What should be covered?
items.text:
For embedded systems requirements typically define:

  • System behavior
  • Timing constraints
  • Hardware interaction
  • Error handling
  • Resource limitations
  • Public C Interface (API) They should describe what the software does, not how it does it.

items.title: Verification Strategy
items.text:
Each requirement should be verifiable via:

  • Unit tests
  • Integration tests
  • Hardware tests/measurements
  • Static analysis
  • Code inspection Example:

Timing requirements must be verified using oscilloscope measurements or processor cycle counter analysis on the target.

items.title: Functional Requirements
items.text:
Functional requirements should describe the system‚Äôs behavior during normal operation and in defined edge or fault conditions. Less precise:

The module must sample the ADC every 1 ms. More precise: The module must sample the ADC with a nominal period of 1 ms and a tolerance of ¬±5 The second version defines a measurable timing constraint and can be verified during testing.

items.title: Hardware Interface Requirements
items.text:
Hardware interface requirements should define how the software interacts with the underlying hardware.

  • GPIO direction and behavior.
  • ADC resolution.
  • SPI/I2C configuration.
  • CAN frame format.
  • Interrupt usage. Example:

The SPI interface must operate as master in Mode 0 at a clock frequency of 1 MHz. The module must transmit a CAN frame with standard ID 0x123 and a period of 100 ms.

items.title: Non-Functional Requirements
items.text:
Timing:

  • The interrupt handler must complete within 20 ¬µs under worst-case execution conditions.
  • The control loop must be executed with a nominal period of 5 ms and a tolerance of ¬±1 %. Memory:
  • The module must not use more than 8 KB of RAM, including static allocation and stack usage.
  • The module must not use dynamic memory allocation (e.g., malloc, calloc, realloc). CPU Usage:
  • The module must not exceed 15 % CPU usage at a 100 Hz update rate on the target platform. Safety:
  • The system must enter a defined safe state within 10 ms after a watchdog timeout.
